What is matter?
questions.answer: Anything that has mass and occupies space is called matter. All living and non-living things are made of matter. Matter is made up of very small particles called atoms or molecules.

questions.question: Name the three physical states of matter.
questions.answer: The three physical states of matter are solid, liquid and gas. They differ in shape, volume and particle movement. These differences are due to intermolecular forces.

questions.question: Why do solids have definite shape?
questions.answer: Particles in solids are very closely packed and vibrate at fixed positions. Strong intermolecular force holds them tightly. Hence solids keep their shape.

questions.question: Why do gases occupy all available space?
questions.answer: Gas particles have very weak intermolecular force. They move freely in all directions. Therefore gases spread and fill the entire container.

questions.question: What is intermolecular force?
questions.answer: It is the force of attraction between particles of matter. It decides how closely particles stay together. Stronger force means less movement of particles.

questions.question: Define element.
questions.answer: An element is a pure substance made of only one type of atom. All particles of an element are identical. It cannot be broken into simpler substances by chemical methods.

questions.question: Define compound.
questions.answer: A compound is formed when two or more elements chemically combine in fixed proportion. Its properties are different from its constituent elements. Example: water.

questions.question: Define mixture.
questions.answer: A mixture contains two or more substances physically mixed. The components retain their properties and proportions can change. Example: air, milk.

questions.question: Why is air called a mixture?
questions.answer: Air contains gases like nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide and argon. These gases are not chemically bonded. Their proportions can vary.

questions.question: What is an alloy?
questions.answer: An alloy is a mixture of two or more metals or a metal and non-metal. It has improved properties. Example: brass is copper and zinc.

questions.question: What is solution?
questions.answer: A solution is a homogeneous mixture of solute and solvent. Its composition is uniform throughout. Example: salt dissolved in water.

questions.question: Define solute and solvent.
questions.answer: Solute is the substance present in smaller amount that dissolves. Solvent is present in larger amount and dissolves the solute. Example: salt is solute, water is solvent.

questions.question: What is suspension?
questions.answer: Suspension is a heterogeneous mixture of solid and liquid. Particles are large and settle down. It can be separated by filtration.

questions.question: What is colloid?
questions.answer: Colloid is a heterogeneous mixture with very small particles dispersed evenly. It scatters light and cannot be separated by filtration. Example: milk.

questions.question: What is Tyndall effect?
questions.answer: It is scattering of light by colloidal particles. It makes the path of light visible. Solutions do not show this effect.

questions.question: Why can solutions pass through filter paper?
questions.answer: Particles of solution are very small and dissolved completely. They pass through filter paper easily. Hence cannot be separated by filtration.

questions.question: Why can suspension be separated by filtration?
questions.answer: Suspension has large solid particles. These particles cannot pass through filter paper. Hence they remain as residue.

questions.question: What is phase?
questions.answer: A phase is a part of matter having uniform composition. Each visible separate part of mixture is a phase. Oil and water form two phases.

questions.question: Define homogeneous mixture.
questions.answer: Homogeneous mixture has only one phase. Composition is same everywhere. Example: salt solution.

questions.question: Define heterogeneous mixture.
questions.answer: Heterogeneous mixture has more than one phase. Components are unevenly distributed. Example: sand in water.

questions.question: What are organic compounds?
questions.answer: Organic compounds contain carbon and hydrogen. On heating they leave black carbon residue. Example: sugar, urea, glucose.

questions.question: What are inorganic compounds?
questions.answer: Inorganic compounds generally do not contain carbon. They do not leave black residue on heating. Example: salt, limestone.

questions.question: What are complex compounds?
questions.answer: Complex compounds contain metal atoms in large molecular structures. Example: chlorophyll has magnesium, hemoglobin has iron.

questions.question: What is molecular formula?
questions.answer: Molecular formula shows symbols and number of atoms of elements in a compound. Subscripts indicate atom numbers. Example: H2O.

questions.question: What is valency?
questions.answer: Valency is the combining capacity of an atom. It shows how many bonds an atom can form. Hydrogen has valency one.

questions.question: Why is hydrogen used to find valency of elements?
questions.answer: Hydrogen has valency one. Number of hydrogen atoms combined with an element shows its valency. Hence it is used as reference.

questions.question: Explain cross multiplication method.
questions.answer: Valencies of elements are crossed and written as subscripts. Then formula is simplified. It helps to write correct molecular formula.

questions.question: Why is water a compound and not mixture?
questions.answer: Water has fixed ratio of hydrogen and oxygen. Its properties are different from both gases. Hence it is a compound.

questions.question: Why does milk retain properties of its components?
questions.answer: Milk is a mixture of water, fats and proteins. Components are not chemically combined. Therefore properties are retained.

questions.question: Why is brass called solid solution?
questions.answer: Brass is mixture of copper and zinc in solid state. Components are uniformly mixed. Hence it is solid in solid solution.

questions.question: Why does sugar turn black on heating?
questions.answer: Sugar is organic compound containing carbon. On heating, carbon remains as black residue. Other elements escape as gases.

questions.question: Why does iron and sulphur mixture attract magnet?
questions.answer: Iron remains in free state in mixture. Its magnetic property remains unchanged. Hence magnet attracts iron particles.

questions.question: Why does iron sulphide not attract magnet?
questions.answer: Iron and sulphur form a new compound. Properties of elements disappear. Iron no longer shows magnetic property.

questions.question: Why are properties of compound different from elements?
questions.answer: Chemical bonding forms new substance. Original properties of elements are lost. New properties appear in compound.

questions.question: Give two examples of gaseous elements.
questions.answer: Oxygen and nitrogen are gaseous elements. They exist as O2 and N2 molecules. Both are present in air.

questions.question: Give two examples of liquid elements.
questions.answer: Mercury and bromine are liquid elements. They remain in liquid state at room temperature.

questions.question: Give two examples of colloids.
questions.answer: Milk and fog are examples of colloids. In milk, fat droplets are dispersed in water.

questions.question: Why do liquids flow?
questions.answer: Particles of liquids have moderate intermolecular force. They can slide over each other. Hence liquids can flow.

questions.question: Why are gases compressible?
questions.answer: Gas particles are far apart. Large empty space is present between them. Hence gases can be compressed.

questions.question: Why are solids incompressible?
questions.answer: Particles are tightly packed with very little space. Strong force keeps them close. Hence compression is difficult.

questions.question: Why does oxygen support combustion?
questions.answer: Oxygen helps substances to burn by reacting with them. It supplies oxygen for chemical reaction. Hence it supports combustion.

questions.question: Why does water extinguish fire?
questions.answer: Water cools burning substance and cuts off oxygen supply. Fire cannot continue without oxygen. Hence fire stops.

questions.question: What is chemical bond?
questions.answer: Chemical bond is force that holds atoms together in molecule. It forms during chemical combination. It gives stability.

questions.question: Why is proportion fixed in compounds?
questions.answer: Atoms combine in definite ratio based on valency. Structure of molecule is fixed. Hence proportion remains constant.

questions.question: Why is proportion variable in mixtures?
questions.answer: Components are not chemically bonded. They can be mixed in any ratio. Hence proportion can change.

questions.question: Why is air gas in gas solution?
questions.answer: All components of air are gases. They mix uniformly and form single phase. Hence it is gas in gas solution.

questions.question: What is dissolution?
questions.answer: Process of dissolving solute in solvent to form solution is dissolution. Example: dissolving salt in water.

questions.question: Why does colloid not settle down?
questions.answer: Colloidal particles are very small and remain dispersed. Gravity cannot pull them down easily. Hence they do not settle.

questions.question: Why is milk called heterogeneous mixture?
questions.answer: Milk has fat and protein particles dispersed in water. It has more than one phase microscopically. Hence it is heterogeneous.

questions.question: What is LPG?
questions.answer: LPG is liquefied petroleum gas. It mainly contains propane and butane. It is used as cooking fuel.

questions.question: Why is diamond hard?
questions.answer: Diamond has strong covalent bonds between carbon atoms. Structure is very rigid. Hence it is extremely hard.

questions.question: Why are alloys useful?
questions.answer: Alloys have better strength and resistance. They improve properties of metals. Hence they are widely used.

questions.question: Why is bronze harder than copper?
questions.answer: Bronze is alloy of copper and tin. Tin atoms disturb copper structure and increase hardness. Hence bronze is stronger.

questions.question: Why does solution appear transparent?
questions.answer: Particles are very small and do not scatter light. Light passes through easily. Hence solution looks transparent.

questions.question: Why does suspension appear opaque?
questions.answer: Large particles scatter light strongly. Light cannot pass through. Hence suspension looks opaque.

questions.question: What is salinity?
questions.answer: Salinity is amount of dissolved salts in water. It is expressed in percentage. Different seas have different salinity.

questions.question: Why does sea water taste salty?
questions.answer: Sea water contains dissolved salts. These salts give salty taste. It is an example of solution.

questions.question: Why does mixture not have chemical formula?
questions.answer: Mixture has no fixed composition. Components are not bonded. Hence no definite chemical formula exists.

questions.question: Why is hydrogen combustible?
questions.answer: Hydrogen reacts easily with oxygen producing heat and flame. Hence it burns readily and is combustible.

questions.question: Why is oxygen not combustible?
questions.answer: Oxygen itself does not burn but supports burning of other substances. It does not act as fuel.

questions.question: Why are properties of mixture retained?
questions.answer: Components are physically mixed and not chemically bonded. Each retains its individual properties.

questions.question: Why is salt solution homogeneous?
questions.answer: Salt dissolves completely in water. Composition is same everywhere. Hence only one phase is present.

questions.question: Why does fog show Tyndall effect?
questions.answer: Fog contains tiny water droplets. These scatter light. Hence Tyndall effect is seen.

questions.question: Why is steel an alloy?
questions.answer: Steel is mixture of iron and carbon. Components are mixed uniformly. Hence it is an alloy.

questions.question: Why does LPG have strong smell?
questions.answer: Odorant is added to LPG for safety. It helps detect leakage. Natural LPG is odorless.

questions.question: Why is filtration not useful for colloids?
questions.answer: Colloidal particles are smaller than filter pores. They pass through filter paper. Hence filtration fails.

questions.question: Why do gases diffuse faster?
questions.answer: Gas particles move freely and rapidly. Distance between them is large. Hence diffusion is fast.

questions.question: Why is iron nail shiny?
questions.answer: Iron is a metal and shows lustre. Fresh surface reflects light. Hence it appears shiny.

questions.question: Why does coal break on hammering?
questions.answer: Coal is non-metal and brittle. It does not flatten but breaks into pieces. Hence it breaks on hammering.

questions.question: Why does copper flatten on hammering?
questions.answer: Copper is malleable metal. It can be beaten into sheets. Hence it flattens on hammering.

questions.question: Why is solution called true mixture?
questions.answer: Particles are evenly distributed and invisible. It forms single phase. Hence it is called true mixture.

questions.question: Why does lime water turn milky with CO2?
questions.answer: Carbon dioxide reacts with lime water forming calcium carbonate. This forms white precipitate and turns milky.

questions.question: Why are gases lighter than solids?
questions.answer: Gas particles are far apart and mass per volume is less. Hence density is low compared to solids.

questions.question: Why is mercury used in thermometers?
questions.answer: Mercury expands uniformly with temperature. It is visible and does not stick to glass. Hence used in thermometers.

questions.question: Why are chemical formulas fixed?
questions.answer: Atoms combine in fixed ratios based on valency. Structure of compound is constant. Hence formula is fixed.

questions.question: Why is glucose organic compound?
questions.answer: Glucose contains carbon and hydrogen. On heating it leaves carbon residue. Hence it is organic compound.

questions.question: Why is blue vitriol inorganic?
questions.answer: Blue vitriol does not contain carbon-hydrogen bonds. It leaves residue on heating. Hence it is inorganic.

questions.question: Why are metals malleable?
questions.answer: Metal atoms can slide over each other without breaking bonds. Hence they can be beaten into sheets.

questions.question: Why are non-metals brittle?
questions.answer: They have rigid structure and weak bonding. On force, bonds break. Hence they shatter easily.

questions.question: Why does compound form new substance?
questions.answer: Atoms chemically combine forming new molecules. Chemical bonds change structure. Hence new substance forms.

questions.question: Why is air essential for burning?
questions.answer: Air contains oxygen which supports combustion. Without oxygen burning cannot occur. Hence air is necessary.

questions.question: Why are chemical reactions irreversible?
questions.answer: New substances are formed with different properties. Original substances cannot be recovered easily.

questions.question: Why is mixture easy to separate?
questions.answer: Components are not chemically bonded. Physical methods like filtration can separate them.

questions.question: Why is compound difficult to separate?
questions.answer: Atoms are chemically bonded. Physical methods cannot break bonds. Chemical reactions are needed.

questions.question: Why does gas have no fixed volume?
questions.answer: Gas expands to fill container. Particles move freely. Hence volume depends on container size.

questions.question: Why do liquids take shape of container?
questions.answer: Particles can slide over each other. They flow and adjust shape. But volume remains same.

questions.question: Why does mixture not show chemical change?
questions.answer: No new bonds are formed. Substances only mix physically. Hence no chemical change occurs.

questions.question: Why is oxygen diatomic?
questions.answer: Two oxygen atoms bond to form stable molecule O2. Single oxygen atom is unstable.

questions.question: Why does compound have fixed melting point?
questions.answer: Structure and bonding are uniform. Hence energy needed to melt is fixed. Therefore melting point is constant.

questions.question: Why does mixture melt over range?
questions.answer: Components melt at different temperatures. Hence melting occurs over range instead of fixed point.

questions.question: Why is distilled water pure?
questions.answer: It contains only H2O molecules. No dissolved salts or gases are present. Hence it is pure compound.

questions.question: Why is sea water not pure?
questions.answer: It contains many dissolved salts and minerals. Hence it is mixture and not pure substance.

questions.question: Why is diamond an element?
questions.answer: Diamond contains only carbon atoms. No other element is present. Hence it is element.

questions.question: Why is baking soda compound?
questions.answer: It has fixed composition NaHCO3. It is formed by chemical combination. Hence it is compound.

questions.question: Why is bronze useful in statues?
questions.answer: Bronze is hard and corrosion resistant. It keeps shape for long time. Hence used for statues.

questions.question: Why is milk nutritious?
questions.answer: Milk contains proteins, fats, lactose and minerals. These are essential nutrients for body.

questions.question: Why is air essential for life?
questions.answer: Oxygen is required for respiration. Carbon dioxide is used by plants. Hence air supports life.

questions.question: Why is fog considered colloid?
questions.answer: Tiny water droplets are dispersed in air. Particle size is in colloidal range. Hence fog is colloid.

questions.question: Why is steel stronger than iron?
questions.answer: Steel contains carbon mixed with iron. Carbon improves strength and hardness. Hence steel is stronger.

questions.question: Why is chemical composition important in classification of matter?
questions.answer: It tells whether particles are same or different. It helps classify matter into element, compound and mixture.
